author: tkstanczak
content:
> at more-than-very-short timescales, the supply curve is still a vertical line at 10 million, so the gasprice that users pay will still be the intersection of that vertical line with their demand curve
<@!273808422753796097> do you plan to push for this change with the assumption that miners take the 100% hit on basefee? they already express big dissatisfaction with the change. On the other hand my opinion is that miners should be looking at arbitrage as the source of revenue if they want to stay competetive.

author: .vbuterin
content: Realistically, I think miners have had plenty of warning and they have already received a lot of unexpected benefit this year from the massive txfees; they're not suffering victims

author: tkstanczak
content: I agree they made tons this year. Probably just the appetite grows (and the additional revenue just shifted the power towards miners).

author: sky.cactus
content: Do the various clients have a mechanism for bisecting transactions in the block (looking at state before/after each) for narrowing splits like that?

author: sky.cactus
content: And then once the offending transaction is found, a mechanism for bisecting state root changes within that transaction?

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, I suppose in this case the split is *probably* outside of a transaction.  ðŸ¤”

author: huntingisland
content: Agreed with <@!273808422753796097>, miners have been paid handsomely over and above expectations this year but those fees are a windfall and won't be maintained
